page.name: new-page
page.title: Home
page.content:
Welcome to TNABA

  • Login
  • Register
  • Donate

Contact Us

615-544-5ABA (5222)
info@tnaba.org

Welcome to the Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes Web Site. TNABA is the home of knowledge, resources, and most of all the home of opportunities. Whether you are a parent of a blind child or a visually impaired adult looking for fun and exciting recreational activities to pass the time, an athlete looking for competitive sports to compete in, or a coach, educator, community program organizer, or a friend looking for ways to adapt activities to create a more inclusive environment for persons with visual disabilities, you have come to the right place. TNABA is dedicated to providing you with the tools, knowledge, and resources to live life to the fullest.

Upcoming Events

News

TNABA Can Come to You to Share the Joys of Adaptive Sports

TNABA has developed a unique & one of a kind outreach and consulting program for physical education teachers, coaches, parents, and others in the community. This combined with our sports programs allows us to reach our mission by educating those in our community while ensuring that blind individuals are able to participate in athletic activities alongside their sighted peers. A team of TNABA athletes and staff can come out to your school, church, or business to demonstrate an adaptive sport, an athlete can come speak at your luncheon or sports banquet to deliver a powerful motivational speech, TNABA staff can provide tips and resources to help you adapt any activity to create a more inclusive environment, or let us inspire your staff at your next team building training. Learn More ...

Looking for a Way to Volunteer and Showcase Your Talents for a Great Cause?

Are you, your friends, church group, or your co-workers looking for an amazing and rewarding opportunity to volunteer? TNABA relys on volunteers as one of the greatest resources for our programs. We have opportunities for every age, skill level, and group size to volunteer as event and program volunteers. Do you have an area of expertise that you would like to share for the greater good? Well look no further! TNABA is always looking for hardworking, outgoing, and enthusiastic individuals to volunteer in one of our skilled volunteer positions. Coaches, referees, program organizers, marketing, and grant writing are just a few areas we are currently recruiting to help further the mission of TNABA. Click Here to Learn How You Can Volunteer With TNABA.

page.caption: About Us
page.name: new-page-2
page.title: About Us
page.content:
What is TNABA?

TNABA, Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes, is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that provides sports and recreational activities for blind or visually impaired men, women, and children of Tennessee. We are the State chapter of the United States Association of Blind Athletes (USABA) and are recognized by the U.S. Paralympic Committee as a Paralympic Sports Club that provides world class programs for adaptive athletes and wounded warriors of all kinds. We provide adaptive programs on 3 different levels which are leisure recreation, health and fitness, and competitive sports. Together with the USABA, we provide local, state, regional, national, and even international opportunities for all children and adults of Tennessee with a visual disability. TNABA also provides outreach and consulting for physical education teachers, coaches, parents, students, and other community members to ensure that blind individuals are able to participate in activities alongside their sighted peers.

The History of TNABA

TNABA was originally formed in 1979 and reestablished in 2009. Over the course of 32 years, many blind athletes from the great State of Tennessee have went on to participate in the Paralympics and have won gold metals for the United States. TNABA has provided over 300 athletes with the opportunity to participate in 10 different sports and health programs. These programs include swimming, track and field, golf, tandem cycling, exercise and fitness classes, yoga and nutrition, bowling, and Goalball to name a few.

Learn more about the Paralympic Games ...

The Purpose and Need for TNABA

Obesity is one of the most serious problems facing our society today. It not only affects people’s health, but their activity level, productivity, and social lives. The issues caused by obesity really put strain on our communities economically, socially, and physically. This could not be truer with the blind community. People with blindness have one of the highest rates of obesity out of all of the minority groups.

Learn more about the purpose and need for TNABA ...

page.caption: Our Mission
page.name: our-mission
page.title: Our Mission
page.content: The mission of the Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes is to enhance the lives and overall health of all blind and visually impaired people of Tennessee; to promote physical fitness through world-class athletic opportunities and recreational activities; to create more opportunities for blind and visually impaired individuals, enhancing their lives and educating the public on their exceptional athletic abilities.

layout.struct: {content}

contents.content: The mission of the Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes is to enhance the lives and overall health of all blind and visually impaired people of Tennessee; to promote physical fitness through world-class athletic opportunities and recreational activities; to create more opportunities for blind and visually impaired individuals, enhancing their lives and educating the public on their exceptional athletic abilities.

page.caption: Purpose and Need
page.name: purpose-and-need
page.title: Purpose and Need
page.content:
Obesity is one of the most serious problems facing our society today. It not only affects people’s health, but their activity level, productivity, and social lives. The issues caused by obesity really put strain on our communities economically, socially, and physically. This could not be truer with the blind community. People with blindness have one of the highest rates of obesity out of all of the minority groups.

An estimated 52,000 blind and visually impaired children are registered in public schools systems nationally every year. Of those students only 17% to 20% of them are included in modified adaptive physical education classes or extracurricular sports and recreational activities. Once they graduate high school that percentage drops to 10% to 14%. More alarming is that less than 6% of our beloved seniors over age 55 are inactive when it comes to health and social activities.

According to Elizabeth Holbrook at MTSU, adults with visual impairment are 1.5 times more likely to be obese or morbidly obese compared to the general population. Reflecting a growing health disparity with the general population, adults with blindness are taking an average of eight daily prescription medications to manage co-morbid conditions, including cardiovascular, metabolic, and musculoskeletal diseases. Although in its infancy, research in this area indicates that the heightened disease rates among adults with blindness are hypo kinetic in nature; meaning, they are due to low levels of physical activity. Adults without vision loss average roughly 7,600 steps per day while adults with visual impairments engage in considerably lower levels of physical activity, averaging just 4,500 steps per day. This level of activity is substantially lower than that needed to produce health benefits and is typically engaged in at very low intensities. The disparity that exists between persons with and without visual impairment begins very early in the lifespan, with noticeable differences in physical fitness appearing during childhood.

How are these startling numbers possible in such an amazing city, State, and a land of opportunity? Three major factors contribute to this growing epidemic, lack of knowledge, lack of resources and support, and transportation. Although physical education teachers, while working on their college degrees, take limited hours of class that address and prepare them for teaching people with disabilities, they report they still lack adequate training, resources, and many times there is not enough funding in their school's budget for purchasing adaptive physical education equipment to create an inclusive environment for a students with visual disabilities. Coaches, community recreation program directors, and parents are unaware of simple adaptations that can be made to give their child the equal playing field of their sighted peers.

A study recently completed by the U.S Paralympics shows that only 1 out of 3 Americans know about the Paralympics or adaptive sports programs. This leads to adults with disabilities feeling left out or inadequate athletically and that doing daily exercises are simply impossible or not needed. Funding, qualified staff, and lack of facilities and space are the greatest problems that face those agencies and non-profit organizations that train, support, and provide opportunities and education to those with disabilities.

In 2011, the Tennessee Division of Vocational Rehabilitation (VR) reported 25,957 Tennesseans with disabilities were registered for vocational rehabilitation services in Tennessee, and that number does not include children and people not receiving VR services. The average annual income for most blind individuals is between $12,000 and $15,000. This statistic shows that lack of funding for gym memberships and even lack of transportation can easily be major factors as to why blind citizens of Tennessee live sedentary lifestyles. TNABA has approximately 30 active blind members throughout Tennessee. Studies have shown that students that participate in physical activities are more likely to attend college, and adults that participate in recreation activities have higher social skills and a higher likely hood of achieving gainful employment. It is no secret that sports teach valuable life lessons such as teamwork, commitment, confidence, and most of all self-worth. In short, healthy people equal a healthy community.

page.caption: Paralympic Sports Club Tennessee
page.name: paralympic-sports-club-tennessee
page.title: Paralympic Sports Club Tennessee
page.content:
TNABA and the U.S. Paralympics Movement

The Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes is now recognized by the U.S. Olympic Committee and Paralympic Committee as an official U.S. Paralympic Sports Club. TNABA is proud to be a part of the Paralympic movement and work with the U.S. Paralympics to bring the spirit of the Paralympic Movement to Tennessee.

The U.S. Paralympics is partnering with community organizations from across the country to create a network of Paralympic Sport Clubs.

Paralympic Sport Clubs are community-based programs developed to involve youth and adults with physical and visual disabilities in sports and physical activity, regardless of skill level. All programs and activities will be based in the community and are run by the local organization.

With 21 million Americans with physical disabilities, including thousands of military personnel who have sustained serious injuries while on active duty, this is an important community need. TNABA is proud to work with other adaptive sports agencies and the Wounded Warriors Program of Fort Campbell to provide all adaptive athletes with the resources and tools to succeed in their dreams of athletics.

What is the Paralympics?

The following information is from the article Paralympic Games found on Wikipedia.

The Paralympic Games are a major international multi-sport event where athletes with physical disabilities compete; this includes athletes with mobility disabilities, amputations, blindness, and Cerebral Palsy. There are Winter and Summer Paralympic Games, which are held immediately following their respective Olympic Games. All Paralympic Games are governed by the International Paralympic Committee (IPC).

The Paralympics have grown from a small gathering of British World War II veterans in 1948 to become one of the largest international sporting events by the early 21st century. Paralympians strive for equal treatment with Olympic athletes without disabilities, but there is a large funding gap between Olympic and Paralympic athletes. There are also sports, such as track and field, that are resistant to Paralympians who wish to compete with athletes without disabilities, though there have been Paralympians who have participated in the Olympic Games.

The Paralympic Games include athletes with physical disabilities, and are run in parallel with the Olympic Games, while the IOC-recognized Special Olympics World Games include athletes with intellectual disabilities, and the Deaflympics include deaf athletes. The present formal explanation for the name "Paralympic" is that it is derived from the Greek preposition παρά, pará ("beside" or "alongside") and thus refers to a competition held in parallel with the Olympic Games. The Summer Games of 1988 held in Seoul was the first time the term "Paralympic" came into official use.

Given the wide variety of disabilities that Paralympic athletes have, there are several categories in which the athletes compete. The allowable disabilities are broken down into six broad categories. The categories are: amputee, Cerebral Palsy, intellectual disability, wheelchair, visually impaired, and Les Autres (literally "The Others", which are athletes with disabilities that do not fall into the other five categories; these include dwarfism, multiple sclerosis, and congenital deformities). These categories are broken down further into classifications, which vary from sport to sport. The classification system has led to cheating controversies revolving around athletes who over-stated their disabilities in addition to the use of performance-enhancing drugs seen in other events.

Videos

Check out these great videos to learn more about TNABA and the U.S. Paralympics Sports Club Program and Movement.

layout.struct: {content}

contents.content:
TNABA and the U.S. Paralympics Movement

The Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes is now recognized by the U.S. Olympic Committee and Paralympic Committee as an official U.S. Paralympic Sports Club. TNABA is proud to be a part of the Paralympic movement and work with the U.S. Paralympics to bring the spirit of the Paralympic Movement to Tennessee.

The U.S. Paralympics is partnering with community organizations from across the country to create a network of Paralympic Sport Clubs.

Paralympic Sport Clubs are community-based programs developed to involve youth and adults with physical and visual disabilities in sports and physical activity, regardless of skill level. All programs and activities will be based in the community and are run by the local organization.

With 21 million Americans with physical disabilities, including thousands of military personnel who have sustained serious injuries while on active duty, this is an important community need. TNABA is proud to work with other adaptive sports agencies and the Wounded Warriors Program of Fort Campbell to provide all adaptive athletes with the resources and tools to succeed in their dreams of athletics.

page.caption: Events
page.name: events
page.title: Events
page.content:
TNABA always has something for everyone! Check out what activities are waiting for you. All of our programs and events are open to the entire community. We encourage our visually challenged friends to bring along their family and sighted friends. In fact, we design our activities to be inclusive and allow anyone, no matter their vision level, to enjoy sports and recreation together. Whether you are looking for recreational and leisure activities, to improve your health and fitness, or to compete regionally, nationally, and even internationally, we have something for you. If we do not have what your looking for, suggest it; we will find the resources for you.

View the calendar of events to see what is going on ...

To find out more about an event or program, access the program specific pages from the main drop down menu under Events, or you can select them from the Events Menu on the right side of the page. If you would like to sign up for a particular event you can fill out the form on the program pages. If you have further questions about an event, you will find a link to contact the program or event coordinator for that activity on our program pages.

We always welcome individual and group volunteers to assist in our events.

Learn more about volunteering with TNABA ...

Community Days

In our efforts to educate the community of the adaptations of sports and recreational activities, and the exceptional athletic abilities of those athletes that use them, TNABA hosts Community Days. These are events dedicated to showing our neighbors and friends through hands on experiences, what it is like to participate in sports through the eyes of a person who is blind or has low vision. Since this outreach program has started in 2011, we have had hundreds of participants in sports like Goalball, bowling, and Tandem Cycling. We invite you to check out one of these great experiences for yourself. Sign up your family, company, youth or church groups, athletic teams, or your group of friends for a great day outing.

page.caption: Achilles International Nashville
page.name: achilles-international-nashville
page.title: Achilles International Nashville
page.content:
RUN WITH US!
McCabe Community Center
Every Wednesday
6:30 PM - 8 PM, Rain or Shine
Refreshments Provided

Achilles International Nashville is a non-profit organization that welcomes all people with physical challenges to the wonderful world of RUNNING!

Volunteer Guides

Volunteer guides function as an athlete’s eyes, ears, guide, and motivator. Volunteers can participate in many ways, including:

  • Help runners with disabilities become familiar and proficient with special equipment.
  • Participate in weekly workouts.
  • Provide guidance and running advice during races and marathons.
  • Help with race-day logistics.

Member Athletes

Achilles welcomes and encourages anyone with a disability or physical challenge to RUN!

  • In Achilles parlance, running means many things. It means conventional running, of course. But it also refers to walking, wheeling, hopping, or swinging through crutches. In other words, any form of locomotion that gets you through the route!
  • Physical challenges include, but are not limited to, amputation, cerebral palsy, cancer, multiple sclerosis, organ transplants, paraplegia, stroke, traumatic brain injury, and visual impairment.
                  

To Learn More

Sarah Hart - (615) 483-5823, achillesnashville@gmail.com
www.achillesinternational.org
www.facebook.com/AchillesInternationalNashville

Photo Gallery

* Click on photos to enlarge.

Video

page.caption: Project HEALTH
page.name: project-health
page.title: Project HEALTH
page.content:
What is Project HEALTH?

Project HEALTH "Helping Every American Learn To be Healthy" is a program of the Sports 4 All Foundation (S4AF). The mission of S4AF is to improve the quality of life of individuals with disabilities by providing funding, equipment, programming, and education to enable full participation in sports and recreational activities. Project HEALTH is funded and supported by the Tennessee Council on Developmental Disabilities, Baptist Healing Trust, the Predators Foundation, and Metro Parks and Recreation Department.

Project HEALTH Circuit Training

Monday Nights: 5:00 PM - 6:00 PM

Project HEALTH teaches a weekly circuit training class with TNABA. This class is open to the public and is fully inclusive of ALL abilities. Each class opens with light exercises and stretches to get the body warmed up. Then, we move into Circuit Training which combines strength training (with resistance bands), toning exercises, and cardio to get the blood pumping, muscles building, and calories burning. The last 15 minutes of the class are cool-down moves that focus on toning, balance, and flexibility. Come early for nutrition tips and discussion.

Admission: TNABA members are FREE and non-members are $5

General HEALTH Tips

1 lb = 3,500 calories
Translation: To burn 1 pound per week; you must cut or burn and extra 500 calories per day.

Plan of Action:

  • Increase fruits and vegetables; Decrease meat and processed foods.
  • Increase physical activity. Try walking a half mile every day until you can walk 2 miles per day. 1 miles typically = 100 calories.
  • Instead of catching up with a friend over coffee or dinner, meet them for a walk. It is perfect for chatting. You should stay at a pace that gets you out of breath but you can still carry on a conversation.
  • Find yourself sitting at home while you are watching television, listening to music, talking with your family, be creative and do sit-ups, side leans, knee raises, anything to keep moving instead of sitting still.

Need fitness or nutrition advice or tips? Just email Waverly at waverlyann@s4af.org. Waverly is our very own Sports 4 All trainer. She is here to help you with all of your questions, and she can even help you plan a diet and exercise program that will maximize your body’s fullest potential.

page.caption: Membership
page.name: membership
page.title: Membership
page.content:
Member Benefits

  • Opportunity to participate in sports and recreational activities, fitness and yoga classes, camps and clinics as well as local and state competitions
  • Calendar of athletic events and conferences for the entire year
  • Contact information for other individuals with similar athletic interests in your area
  • Web site with up-to-date information on TNABA news and events
  • Access to fitness and nutrition education and tools
  • Access to TNABA-specific support list-serves
  • Your very own Member Development Account
  • Eligibility for member-only scholarships
  • Free or discounted Event Tickets to sporting events and activities around town
  • And Much More!

Annual Membership Dues

Dues can be paid online on the Membership Dues page.

  • $15 - Adult (21 years of age and older)
  • $10 - Youth (13 to 20 years of age)
  • $10 - Junior (5 to 12 years of age)

Submit Membership Application

If you would like to become a member of TNABA, you have three options to submit your forms and dues.

  • Submit Application Online

page.caption: Did You Know?
page.name: did-you-know
page.title: Did You Know?
page.content:
Did you know there are an estimated 52,000 school-aged children who are blind or have visual impairments in the United States, of whom nearly 70% do not participate in even a limited physical education curriculum? The barriers that these youths face are primarily the consequences of transitioning from residential schools, where physical educators deliver specialized services in relatively small classes to public schools, where educators have less knowledge, time and resources with which to apply to students who are visually impaired. Other barriers include:

  • prejudicial attitudes that persons who are blind or visually impaired cannot participate in sports;
  • lack of knowledge, tools, and equipment necessary to provide adaptive physical education;
  • child’s lack of skill development which, in turn, affects confidence and willingness to participate in unfamiliar athletic activity;
  • there is no one on one instruction due to large public school classes and community programs such as exercise and yoga class. Often times the instructor gives visual instructions that leave the blind individual feeling lost or excluded and not getting anything from the program.

Just as those that are sighted, individuals that are blind or visually impaired deserve the same opportunities to learn leadership and teamwork and to gain self-esteem and confidence through sports.

Recent research compiled by the U.S. Department of Education shows that recreation and sports activities provide persons with disabilities the opportunity to increase mobility, independence, and socialization. Studies also indicate that athletic activity is influential in preventing a decline in physical, cognitive and psychosocial functioning. All of these issues have been demonstrated to be frequent consequences felt by individuals with disabilities who lead sedentary lifestyles. In addition, research has demonstrated that youth involvement in athletics results in higher Grade Point Averages, better time management skills, and improved performance on standardized tests.

The benefits of sports and recreation have also been shown to continue from adolescence to adulthood. A recent survey of the USABA members revealed not only did they benefit academically from their involvement in sports during elementary through high school, but 57% of USABA members continued on to higher education pursuing college degrees. This percentage more than doubles the national average of 23% for their peers with visual impairments. USABA members also beat the national unemployment rate, reporting only 35% compared to the national average of 70%.

  • there is no one on one instruction due to large public school classes and community programs such as exercise and yoga class. Often times the instructor gives visual instructions that leave the blind individual feeling lost or excluded and not getting anything from the program.

Just as those that are sighted, individuals that are blind or visually impaired deserve the same opportunities to learn leadership and teamwork and to gain self-esteem and confidence through sports.

Recent research compiled by the U.S. Department of Education shows that recreation and sports activities provide persons with disabilities the opportunity to increase mobility, independence, and socialization. Studies also indicate that athletic activity is influential in preventing a decline in physical, cognitive and psychosocial functioning. All of these issues have been demonstrated to be frequent consequences felt by individuals with disabilities who lead sedentary lifestyles. In addition, research has demonstrated that youth involvement in athletics results in higher Grade Point Averages, better time management skills, and improved performance on standardized tests.

The benefits of sports and recreation have also been shown to continue from adolescence to adulthood. A recent survey of the USABA members revealed not only did they benefit academically from their involvement in sports during elementary through high school, but 57% of USABA members continued on to higher education pursuing college degrees. This percentage more than doubles the national average of 23% for their peers with visual impairments. USABA members also beat the national unemployment rate, reporting only 35% compared to the national average of 70%.

page.caption: Community Days
page.name: community-days
page.title: Community Days
page.content: In our efforts to educate the community of the adaptations of sports and recreational activities, and the exceptional athletic abilities of those athletes that use them, TNABA hosts Community Days. These are events dedicated to showing our neighbors and friends through hands on experiences, what it is like to participate in sports through the eyes of a person who is blind or has low vision. Since this outreach program has started in 2011, we have had hundreds of participants in sports like Goalball, bowling, and Tandem Cycling. We invite you to check out one of these great experiences for yourself. Sign up your family, company, youth or church groups, athletic teams, or your group of friends for a great day outing.

page.caption: Support Us
page.name: support-us
page.title: Support Us
page.content:
There are two main ways to support the Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes; they are through donations and volunteering.

Donations

TNABA has no paid staff so we depend upon the generosity of people and organizations like you to support our programs that change the lives of so many. We also accept donations of equipment, supplies, and services that help reduce operating costs. You can even sponsor an athlete to help them with costs associated with equipment and travel expenses to events. We accept all forms of donations. TNABA is recognized by the IRS as a 501(c)3 non-profit organization, and all contributions are tax deductible.

Learn more about donations ...

Volunteering

TNABA is ran by an all volunteer Board of Directors and staff. We thrive on the gracious donations of time that individuals and groups spend with TNABA events and projects. We have opportunities for everyone of any age or skill set. We have event opportunities and skilled volunteer positions to meet your time commitments and desire. They do not call Tennessee the Volunteer State for nothing!

Learn more about volunteering ...

page.caption: Donate
page.name: donate
page.title: Donate
page.content:
Donate to TNABA

Thank you for your interest in supporting the Tennessee Association of Blind Athletes and its programs for children, youth, adults and Veterans who are blind and visually impaired. It is through the support of our many individual donors, corporate sponsors and foundation grantors that we are able to make an impact in dreams of our members, no matter how small or big. We thank you for investing in the future and dreams of Tennessee athletes who are blind or visually impaired.

All cash donations can be made by check or online through Paypal. If you like to make your donation through check, you may send it to:

TNABA
1081 Zophi Street
Nashville, TN 37216

We thank you for your continued support in TNABA's efforts to creating a more active community and helping blind individuals reach personal and athletic goals. TNABA is recognized by the IRS as a 501(c)3 non-profit organization. All contributions are tax deductible.

One Time or Reoccurring Donations Online

You can make a secure donation online through PayPal. There are two options when making a donation through PayPal. You can make a one time donation and or setup a reoccurring donation using the the PayPal Subscription feature. Reoccurring donations will automatically be processed annually. Remember that all donations are tax deductible. We will send you a "Receipt of Donation" letter for your records upon your donation.

Make One Time PayPal Donation



Make Reoccurring PayPal Donation

Sponsor an Athlete

If you would like to help sponsor a specific athlete for an event or for the year you may make a tax deductible donation into that athletes Member Development Account. Your generous donation will help an athlete with transportation, entrance fees, lodging, personal equipment, membership dues, and any other expenses she or he may incur while attending competitions, camps, and events.

Matching Gifts

Your gift can be doubled, or even tripled, if you or your spouse are employed by a company with a matching gift program. All you need to do is obtain a matching gift form from your Human Resource department, fill it out, and mail it to:

TNABA
1081 Zophi Street
Nashville, TN 37216

In-kind Donations

Products or services, which have the effect of reducing our operating costs, are greatly appreciated.

Corporate Sponsorships

TNABA relies on the relationships and generosity of the businesses in our community. Corporate sponsorships are truly a win-win partnership between your business and TNABA. We offer many advertising benefits for you as a way to say thank you for your support.

Fundraising Donations

Donating items that can be used in fundraisers such as craft shows, silent auctions, car washes, use of facilities, and others can go a long way in the production of a great fundraiser. Fundraisers are the main way we earn money to support TNABA and we are not afraid of working hard for a cause we believe in so deeply.

page.caption: Volunteer
page.name: volunteer
page.title: Volunteer
page.content:
Volunteer Opportunities

Volunteers are the core of any nonprofit organization. We understand that financial donations may not be possible, but giving your time and energy is another option that is just as valuable as donations. TNABA is in need of qualified and responsible volunteers to assist with a variety of tasks from assisting at athletic events, sitting on important committees, to performing administrative duties. Our organization is fully staffed by volunteers. Volunteering and community service looks great on resumes and college applications, and goes a long way in building a stronger community. If you would like to volunteer with us, please contact the TNABA Volunteer Coordinator via email at volunteer@tnaba.org.

page.caption: Resources
page.name: resources
page.title: Resources
page.content:
Arts and Entertainment

Tennessee Performing Arts Center

Web site: www.tpac.org

Provides live narration for blind and visually impaired patrons. Braille and large print programs are also available. Call Lori Ward for details at 615-782-4077.

Tennessee Performing Arts Center Accessibility Information

Regal Cinemas

Web site: www.regmovies.com

Has the equipment at Hollywood 27, Opry Mills 20 and Providence Stadium 14 to offer audio description of movies when the track is available. A blind person may also bring a sighted person to guide and describe for movies not available with audio description at no charge for the sighted person. Call for current movie title featuring audio description at:

  • Hollywood 27: 615-463-7705
  • Opry Mills 20: 615-514-3456
  • Providence Stadium 14: 615-773-4400

Benefits and Services

Social Security Administration

Web site: www.ssa.gov

The Social Security Administration must provide correspondence in accessible formats. Call 1-877-708-1776 for more information.

Financial

Free Credit Reports

Call 1-877-322-8228 to receive free credit reports from the three major reporting agencies in accessible formats.

Shopping

Provide a Guide

Provide a guide security officers at local malls will escort blind and visually impaired customers from store to store. Salespeople assist with shopping within the store, but when you are ready to go on to your next stop, they will return to guide you. It is recommended that you call the mall office and ask to be connected with security to set this up ahead of your arrival. Please let them know the day and approximate time you will need their service and which entrance you will arrive at.

Tourism

The Parthenon

Web site: www.nashville.gov/Parthenon

The Parthenon is expanding its "touchable arts" program with sounds and touchable items to better comprehend scenes in paintings, etc. There are scaled replicas of statues and architectural features of the building. Contact D.G. Lester at 615-862-8431 for more details.

The Hermitage

Web site: www.thehermitage.com

The Hermitage has audible wands to dial a number associated with a specific exhibit to hear audible information. Call 615-889-2941 for more details.

Country Music Hall of Fame

Web site: countrymusichalloffame.org

The Country Music Hall of Fame has audible wands to dial a specific number associated with an exhibit to hear corresponding information. Call 615-416-2001 for more details.

Transportation

Southwest Airlines

Web site: www.southwest.com

Southwest Airlines will assist customers with disabilities and you can even check special online fares. Call 1-866-281-8464 for more information.
